members.text: There is no need for preemptive policies against bubbles because there are no bubbles on the housing market in the first place. #basic
members.title: No bubbles, no preemption

members.text: There is no need for preemptive policies against bubbles because any potential bubbles are, macroecoomically speaking, harmless. #basic
members.title: Harmless bubbles, no preemption

members.text: Substantial transactions costs render bubbles unlikely.
members.title: Turnover Argument

pcs.text: Sales in the real estate market incur substantial transaction costs.
pcs.title: Untitled 7

pcs.text: If transaction costs are substantial, the market turnover is low.
pcs.title: Untitled 8

pcs.text: If market turnover is low, no “speculative conflagration” develops.
pcs.title: Untitled 9

pcs.text: If no “speculative conflagration” develops, prices do not rise significantly above their fundamentals.
pcs.title: Untitled 10

pcs.text: If prices do not rise significantly above their fundamentals, bubbles cannot occur.
pcs.title: Untitled 11
Bubbles impossible
pcs.text: Bubbles cannot occur in the real estate market.
Sales in the real estate market incur substantial transaction costs.
pcs.title: Untitled 7

pcs.text: If transaction costs are substantial, the market turnover is low.
pcs.title: Untitled 8

pcs.text: If market turnover is low, no “speculative conflagration” develops.
pcs.title: Untitled 9

pcs.text: If no “speculative conflagration” develops, prices do not rise significantly above their fundamentals.
pcs.title: Untitled 10

pcs.text: If prices do not rise significantly above their fundamentals, bubbles cannot occur.
pcs.title: Untitled 11
Bubbles impossible
pcs.text: Bubbles cannot occur in the real estate market.

members.text: As housing markets are local, bubbles will have no substantial effects on the U.S. economy as a whole.
members.title: Spatial Fragmentation Argument

pcs.text: The US housing market is a collection of local markets.
pcs.title: Untitled 15
Local bubbles harmless
pcs.text: It is unlikely that bubbles in local markets have strong detrimental effects on the economy of the whole nation.
It is unlikely that bubbles on the US housing market have strong detrimental effects on the economy of the whole nation.
pcs.title: Untitled 16

pcs.text: The US housing market is a collection of local markets.
pcs.title: Untitled 15
Local bubbles harmless
pcs.text: It is unlikely that bubbles in local markets have strong detrimental effects on the economy of the whole nation.
It is unlikely that bubbles on the US housing market have strong detrimental effects on the economy of the whole nation.
pcs.title: Untitled 16

members.text: As the transaction costs of the sale of second homes are low enough to allow for high turnover and speculative activity, bubbles can develop. #concession
members.title: Speculative Conflagration Argument

pcs.text: Sales of second homes do not incur substantial transaction costs.
pcs.title: Untitled 20

pcs.text: If transaction costs are not substantial, the market turnover can be high.
pcs.title: Untitled 21

pcs.text: If market turnover can be high, “speculative conflagration” can develop.
pcs.title: Untitled 22

pcs.text: If speculative conflagration can develop, prices can rise significantly above their fundamentals.
pcs.title: Untitled 23

pcs.text: If prices can rise significantly above their fundamentals, bubbles can occur.
pcs.title: Untitled 24

pcs.text: Bubbles can occur in the real estate market.
pcs.title: Untitled 25

inferenceRules: Universal instantiation of 2-5 to the housing market

pcs.text: Sales of second homes do not incur substantial transaction costs.
pcs.title: Untitled 20

pcs.text: If transaction costs are not substantial, the market turnover can be high.
pcs.title: Untitled 21

pcs.text: If market turnover can be high, “speculative conflagration” can develop.
pcs.title: Untitled 22

pcs.text: If speculative conflagration can develop, prices can rise significantly above their fundamentals.
pcs.title: Untitled 23

pcs.text: If prices can rise significantly above their fundamentals, bubbles can occur.
pcs.title: Untitled 24

pcs.text: Bubbles can occur in the real estate market.
pcs.title: Untitled 25

inferenceRules: Universal instantiation of 2-5 to the housing market

members.text: Nationwide banking and widespread securitization of mortgages make it unlikely that financial intermediation would be impaired in case house prizes were corrected.
members.title: Diversification Argument

pcs.text: Nationwide banking and widespread securitization diversify the risk of mortgage lenders (in the case of home price declines in some local markets).
pcs.title: Untitled 29

pcs.text: The diversification of risk makes the impairment of financial intermediation (in the case of home price declines in some local markets) unlikely.
pcs.title: Untitled 30

pcs.text: Nationwide banking and widespread securitization make the impairment of financial intermediation (in the case of home price declines in some local markets) unlikely.
pcs.title: Untitled 31

pcs.text: If the impairment of financial intermediation (in the case of home price declines in some local markets) is unlikely, then it is unlikely that bubbles in local markets have strong detrimental effects on the economy of the whole nation.
pcs.title: Untitled 32

pcs.text: Banking is nationwide and securitization is widespread.
pcs.title: Untitled 33

pcs.text: Nationwide banking and widespread securitization diversify the risk of mortgage lenders (in the case of home price declines in some local markets).
pcs.title: Untitled 29

pcs.text: The diversification of risk makes the impairment of financial intermediation (in the case of home price declines in some local markets) unlikely.
pcs.title: Untitled 30

pcs.text: Nationwide banking and widespread securitization make the impairment of financial intermediation (in the case of home price declines in some local markets) unlikely.
pcs.title: Untitled 31

pcs.text: If the impairment of financial intermediation (in the case of home price declines in some local markets) is unlikely, then it is unlikely that bubbles in local markets have strong detrimental effects on the economy of the whole nation.
pcs.title: Untitled 32

pcs.text: Banking is nationwide and securitization is widespread.
pcs.title: Untitled 33

members.text: In the run-up to the financial crisis in 2008, Alan Greenspan put forward a variety of arguments for the following claim:
members.title: Untitled 1
Against Preemption
members.text: Policymakers should not implement preemptive policies against bubbles. #basic
Greenspan argued for this claim by saying that there is no need for such preemption because there are no bubbles and because potential bubbles would be harmless anyway.
members.title: Untitled 2

members.text: At various occassions, Greenspan put forward sophisticated arguments that back one of these basic reasons against preemptive policies.
members.title: Untitled 3

members.text: To start with, Greenspan presented what one might call the @<Turnover Argument> in a testimony before the Joint Economic Committee of the US Congress on 17 April 2002:
members.title: Untitled 4

members.text: "The ongoing strength in the housing market has raised concerns about the possible emergence of a bubble in home prices. However, the analogy often made to the building and bursting of a stock price bubble is imperfect. ... Unlike in the stock market, sales in the real estate market incur substantial transactions costs and, when most homes are sold, the seller must physically move out. Doing so often entails significant financial and emotional costs and is an obvious impediment to stimulating a bubble through speculative trading in homes. Thus, while stock market turnover is more than 100 percent annually, the turnover of home ownership is less than 10 percent annually--scarcely tinder for specula- tive conflagration."
members.title: Untitled 5

members.text: The @<Turnover Argument> justifies the view that under normal circumstances there are no bubbles in the real estate market.
members.title: Untitled 6

members.text: Sales in the real estate market incur substantial transaction costs.
members.title: Untitled 7

members.text: If transaction costs are substantial, the market turnover is low.
members.title: Untitled 8

members.text: If market turnover is low, no “speculative conflagration” develops.
members.title: Untitled 9

members.text: If no “speculative conflagration” develops, prices do not rise significantly above their fundamentals.
members.title: Untitled 10

members.text: If prices do not rise significantly above their fundamentals, bubbles cannot occur.
members.title: Untitled 11
Bubbles impossible
members.text: Bubbles cannot occur in the real estate market.
In the following passage, taken from the same testimony, Greenspan addresses a further difference between the stock market and the real estate market.
members.title: Untitled 12

members.text: "A home in Portland, Oregon is not a close substitute for a home in Portland, Maine, and the “national” housing market is better understood as a collection of small local housing markets. Even if a bubble were to develop in a local market, it would not necessarily have implications for the nation as a whole."
members.title: Untitled 13

members.text: The argument in this passage shall be called the @<Spatial Fragmentation Argument>.
members.title: Untitled 14

members.text: The US housing market is a collection of local markets.
members.title: Untitled 15
Local bubbles harmless
members.text: It is unlikely that bubbles in local markets have strong detrimental effects on the economy of the whole nation.
It is unlikely that bubbles on the US housing market have strong detrimental effects on the economy of the whole nation.
members.title: Untitled 16

members.text: In a testimony before the Joint Committee on 9 June 2005, Greenspan retreated from the @<Turnover Argument>, which had proved untenable in the light of new developments.
members.title: Untitled 17

members.text: "In recent years, the pace of turnover of existing homes has quickened. It appears that a substantial part of the acceleration in turnover reflects the purchase of second homes— either for investment or vacation purposes. Trans- actions in second homes, of course, are not restrained by the same forces that restrict the purchases or sales of primary residences -- an individual can sell without having to move. This suggests that speculative activity may have had a greater role in generating the recent price increases than it has customarily had in the past."
members.title: Untitled 18

members.text: Surging home turnover and a steep climb in home prices contradict premises (1) and (2) of the @<Turnover Argument> of June 2002. Greenspan now argues for exactly the opposite conclusion:
members.title: Untitled 19

members.text: Sales of second homes do not incur substantial transaction costs.
members.title: Untitled 20

members.text: If transaction costs are not substantial, the market turnover can be high.
members.title: Untitled 21

members.text: If market turnover can be high, “speculative conflagration” can develop.
members.title: Untitled 22

members.text: If speculative conflagration can develop, prices can rise significantly above their fundamentals.
members.title: Untitled 23

members.text: If prices can rise significantly above their fundamentals, bubbles can occur.
members.title: Untitled 24

members.text: Bubbles can occur in the real estate market.
members.title: Untitled 25

inferenceRules: Universal instantiation of 2-5 to the housing market

members.text: However, Greenspan stood fast to the @<Spatial Fragmentation Argument> of 2002. In one passage of the 2005 testimony, he added considerations which were meant to endorse premise (2) of that argument in view of possible objections.
members.title: Untitled 26

members.text: "Although we certainly cannot rule out home price declines, especially in some local markets, these declines, were they to occur, likely would not have substantial macroeconomic implications. Nationwide banking and widespread securitization of mortgages make it less likely that financial intermediation would be impaired than was the case in prior episodes of regional house price corrections."
members.title: Untitled 27

members.text: Greenspan hence argues:
members.title: Untitled 28

members.text: Nationwide banking and widespread securitization diversify the risk of mortgage lenders (in the case of home price declines in some local markets).
members.title: Untitled 29

members.text: The diversification of risk makes the impairment of financial intermediation (in the case of home price declines in some local markets) unlikely.
members.title: Untitled 30

members.text: Nationwide banking and widespread securitization make the impairment of financial intermediation (in the case of home price declines in some local markets) unlikely.
members.title: Untitled 31

members.text: If the impairment of financial intermediation (in the case of home price declines in some local markets) is unlikely, then it is unlikely that bubbles in local markets have strong detrimental effects on the economy of the whole nation.
members.title: Untitled 32

members.text: Banking is nationwide and securitization is widespread.
members.title: Untitled 33

sections.title: Subdebate about the existence of bubbles
Subdebate about the consequences of bubbles
